title: 105_s744
content: The Act titled "Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System Act of 1998" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the findings and purposes of the Act. The Fall River Water Users District in South Dakota lacks sufficient water supplies of good quality, leading to health and safety concerns. Severe droughts have left residents without adequate water, forcing them to haul water for their needs. Many resort to using bottled water or distillers due to poor water quality. The Fall River Water Users District in South Dakota faces water supply challenges, leading to health and safety concerns. The State of South Dakota recognizes the District's rural water system, which includes a Madison Aquifer well, water storage reservoirs, pumping stations, and pipelines. The Act aims to ensure a safe and adequate water supply for members, assist in developing water supplies, and promote water conservation. The Act aims to promote water conservation programs by the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System. The Act aims to promote water conservation programs by the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System through defining key terms. The Act defines key terms related to water conservation programs by the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System, including the engineering report, project construction budget, and pumping and operational requirements. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The term "water supply system" pertains to the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System, a nonprofit corporation established in accordance with an engineering report. Federal assistance is provided for the Fall River Water Users District Rural Water System. The Secretary will provide grants for the planning and construction of the water supply system in the Fall River Water Users District. The system will ensure safe municipal, rural, and industrial water supplies, wetlands mitigation, and water conservation within specific boundaries. Grants will not exceed the Federal share under section 9. The Secretary will not obligate funds for the construction of the water supply system until the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act are met and a final engineering report and water conservation plan have been submitted to Congress for at least 90 days. SEC. 5. Mitigation of fish and wildlife losses from water supply system construction and operation will be acre-for-acre based on ecological equivalency. Mitigation to be concurrent with project construction as outlined in the engineering report. SEC. 6. Use of Pick-Sloan Power. The Western Area Power Administration will provide capacity and energy for irrigation and drainage pumping for the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program from May 1 to October 31 each year. The water supply system must operate on a not-for-profit basis and purchase electric service from a qualified preference power supplier. The Western Area Power Administration will provide capacity and energy for irrigation and drainage pumping for the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program. The firm power rate schedule of the Administration will apply, and a contract must be agreed upon by relevant parties to pass through the benefit of the rate schedule to the water supply system. The power supplier of the water supply system can include usual charges for electric service in their charges to the water system. SEC. 7. NO LIMITATION ON WATER PROJECTS IN STATE. This Act does not limit authorization for water projects in South Dakota under current law. SEC. 8. WATER RIGHTS. This Act does not affect State water law, interstate compacts, or water rights. SEC. 9. FEDERAL SHARE. SEC. 9. FEDERAL SHARE. The Federal share is 70 percent of the project construction budget for the water supply system under section 4, plus necessary sums for cost increases after August 1, 1995. SEC. 10. NON-FEDERAL SHARE. The non-Federal share is 30 percent of the project construction budget for the water supply system under section 4, plus necessary sums for cost increases after August 1, 1995. SEC. 11. CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT. SEC. 11. CONSTRUCTION OVERSIGHT. The Secretary of the Interior may provide construction oversight for the water supply system. The funds used for planning and construction may not exceed 3 percent of the total project construction budget for Fall River County, South Dakota. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,600,000 is authorized for planning and construction of the water system, with additional funds for cost increases after August 1, 1995.
